Exposure_Definition: Hours of exposure during the last week to each of 4 types of electronic media
Depression_Measure: CES-D (9-item Center for Epidemiologic Studies-Depression Scale)
Covariates_Adjusted: Baseline CES-D score; age; sex; race (white; African American; Asian; American Indian; other); Hispanic ethnicity; maternal educational level; marital status at follow-up; educational achievement at follow-up
Special_Notes: Gender-specific depression cutoff scores (>=11 for females; >=10 for males). Significant sex interaction for total media exposure (young women had lower odds of developing depression than young men for same exposure).

Exposure_Definition: Self-reported hours per day spent viewing TV (before and after school) and using computer (playing computer games) during leisure time
Covariates_Adjusted: Age at baseline; follow-up time; sex; school (random effect); parental educational level; parental marital status; smoking status; alcohol intake in adolescence
Special_Notes: Split follow-up: 242 individuals with 6-year follow-up (72 months); 193 individuals with 12-year follow-up (144 months). Depression threshold MDI >=20. One participant with history of depression at baseline was excluded but depression was not systematically assessed at baseline.

Exposure_Definition: Self-reported hours per day spent on computer (including playing video or computer games or using computer for something not school work) and watching TV/video programs on usual weekday and weekend day
Depression_Measure: CES-D (Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale)
Covariates_Adjusted: Sex; age; residential background; BMI; perceived family economic status; sleep quality; smoking; alcohol intake; exercise after school; physical activity
Special_Notes: Exposure categorized as <=2 hours/day or >2 hours/day. Study also measured anxiety (SAS cutoff >=50) and psychopathological symptoms (MSQA). Depression cutoff: CES-D >=16. Progression defined as new problems or increased scores. Baseline depression not excluded.

Exposure_Definition: Self-reported time spent watching television; using computer; and texting on average weekdays and weekend days
Covariates_Adjusted: Sex; maternal age; anxiety/depression at 15 years; maternal anxiety and depression; maternal education; parental socioeconomic status; child IQ; parental conflict; presence of child's father; number of people in home; bullying; early family TV use
Special_Notes: Screen time categorized as <1 hour; 1-2 hours; 3+ hours per day; assessed separately for weekdays and weekends. Depression and anxiety coded as three-level ordinal variables (none; symptoms without diagnosis; diagnosis). Multiple imputation used (complete cases n=1869; full sample n=14665). Earlier depression/anxiety (at 7; 10; 13; 15 years) was adjusted for but specific baseline exclusion not stated.

Exposure_Definition: Self-reported hours per day spent watching TV and playing video/computer games on an average school day
Depression_Measure: RCADS (Revised Children's Anxiety and Depression Scale) - MDD subscale
Covariates_Adjusted: Age; sex; race/ethnicity; SES (parental education); school (fixed effect); physical activity; BMI percentile; baseline screen time; baseline emotional disorders
Special_Notes: Reciprocal/bidirectional analysis. Also measured GAD; PD; and SP (using RCADS subscales). Screen time dichotomized as >=4 h/day vs. <4 h/day. Meeting [sub]clinical age- and sex-normed thresholds for emotional disorders. Physical activity moderated some associations. Baseline emotional disorders not excluded.

Exposure_Definition: Using mobile phone >=4 hours per day
Covariates_Adjusted: Age; sex; rural area; paternal education level; family income; overweight; habitual napping; TV/Internet use; chronic medical conditions; perceived study stress; perceived study interest; living expenses
Special_Notes: Depression outcome defined as BDI>=10; primary focus was sleep disturbances with depression as secondary outcome; bidirectional associations examined via cross-lagged analysis

Exposure_Definition: Self-reported hours spent online per week
Followup_Months: 36-48 months (21 years for self-harm; 22 years for depression/anxiety)
Covariates_Adjusted: Sex; SEP (maternal/paternal social class; maternal education); previous mental health problems (sMFQ at 16 years); hours online
Special_Notes: Exposure categorized into tertiles separately by gender. Depression cutoff: sMFQ >=11. Also measured anxiety (GAD-7 >=10) and self-harm. Baseline depression was adjusted for (at age 16) but not excluded. Multiple imputation used for missing data.

Exposure_Definition: Self-reported frequency of video games; social media; and leisure-time internet use (4-point Likert scale: most days; at least once a week; at least once a month; less often/never)
Covariates_Adjusted: Gender; household income; baseline emotional symptoms (SDQ emotional subscale); maternal depression/anxiety history; bullying experience; physical activity; standardized BMI
Special_Notes: Millennium Cohort Study. Exposure measured at age 11; outcome at age 14. Frequency-based categorical exposure (4 levels). sMFQ continuous scores used (range 0-26). Baseline emotional symptoms adjusted for but baseline depression not specifically excluded. Physical activity examined as effect modifier.

Screen_Equipment: Television/movies; video/computer games; phone talking; internet surfing; texting/messaging/emailing
Exposure_Definition: Self-reported time per day spent on: watching/streaming TV/movies; playing video/computer games; talking on phone; surfing internet; texting/messaging/emailing (reported in hours and minutes)
Depression_Measure: CESD-R-10 (Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale Revised-10)
Covariates_Adjusted: Age; race/ethnicity; sex; BMI; school-area median household income; previous year anxiety and depressive symptoms
Special_Notes: COMPASS study. Five types of screen time categorized into 5 levels (0-29 min/day; 30-59 min/day; 1-<2 h/day; 2-<3 h/day; >=3 h/day). Depression cutoff: CESD-R-10 >=10. Also measured anxiety (GAD-7; cutoff >=10). Baseline anxiety and depression symptoms adjusted for but not excluded. Change scores also analyzed.
